Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Model-Based Multidisciplinary Dynamic Decisions in Design

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The complexity of engineered systems such as aerospace vehicles, automobiles, and advanced materials systems has reached a tipping point that challenges existing design and analysis methods. Simplified design models, applied in traditional paradigms, are inadequate for capturing complex system behaviors. Moreover, high-fidelity computer simulation models and experimental tests cannot be fully applied in many situations, due to their high costs. As a result, there is a great need for systematically fusing information from multiple sources, including simulation models with multiple levels of fidelity, and for deciding how best to conduct further simulations at each stage of the design process. This research will create a new decision-making framework to address this need and to guide the design of complex engineered systems. The resulting method is expected to increase the value of the design process in industries such as aerospace, automotive, energy, and consumer electronics by reducing the occurrence of undiscovered problems that occur late in a development cycle and decreasing the budget and schedule required for the design process. The project will also provide interdisciplinary research training and education across aerospace, mechanical, and industrial engineering.

The intellectual significance of this research is to approach the design of a complex system as an information-seeking and knowledge-generation (learning) process that can be modeled as a stochastic discrete-time dynamical system. Information theory and decision science are integrated to make design decisions that involve not only selection of system attributes, but also choices about subsequent information-seeking actions in a design process. An overarching Bayesian spatial random process modeling framework will be established to fuse heterogeneous information from multifidelity simulations and experiments with uncertainty quantification, where the fidelity of models can be either clearly ranked (hierarchical) or not (nonhierarchical). Approaches based on multidisciplinary statistical sensitivity analysis and multidisciplinary uncertainty analysis will be established for managing the couplings and complexity inherent in fusing information across fidelities and disciplines, while maintaining disciplinary autonomy in distributed analyses. The dynamic decision making framework will provide a uniform accounting for many different types of uncertainties, and decision functions grounded in expected utility theory are formulated to guide subsequent design actions. A further critical contribution of this research is to develop heuristic-based strategies for managing the complexity in solving the daunting optimal decision making problem. The framework will be assessed on a testbed problem involving the design of a distributed electric propulsion aircraft concept.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In multidisciplinary design of complex engineered systems such as aerospace vehicles, automobiles, and advanced materials systems, at each stage of the design process a rigorous approach is needed for systematically incorporating information from many different sources (e.g., expert opinion, simplified analytical equation approximations, limited physical experimentation, extensive complex computer simulation modeling within each discipline and with varying levels of accuracy) and then selecting the most appropriate analysis to conduct next at that stage. This collaborative research has created a data fusion approach within a novel dynamic decision-making framework to guide the design of complex engineered systems, incorporating heterogeneous data from disparate multi-accuracy analysis tools or design tasks and optimally allocating resources among data gathering activities for simulation and/or physical experimentation across the different disciplines.  To accomplish this, this work has created (1) a Bayesian framework for combining heterogeneous information, (2) an approach for managing the physics coupling between the different disciplines of the complex system, and (3) decision making strategies and algorithms for use at each stage of the dynamic multidisciplinary design process.

A major novelty of this research is to approach the design of a complex system as an information-seeking and knowledge-generation (learning) process that can be modeled as a stochastic dynamic system. Various information theory and decision science concepts have been integrated within a Gaussian process modeling framework to enable design decisions that involve not only selection of system attributes, but also choices about subsequent (information seeking) actions in a design process.  To accomplish this, this research has created a number of advances in Gaussian process surrogate modeling that include methods to handle categorical design variables, to more accurately quantify uncertainty in the surrogate model, to handle behavior typical in physics-based simulations, and to handle large data sets of high dimension, and to utilize limited high-accuracy data to adjust simulation models via functional calibration. It has also created decision-making frameworks based on enhanced collaborative optimization and model independent adaptive sampling and demonstrated proof-of-concept by developing a computational aerodynamics case study.

The methods developed in this research offer an approach to increase the value of the design process for complex engineered systems in industries such as aerospace and defense, automotive, energy, and consumer electronics. In aerospace and defense, cost and schedule overruns related to the design and development of complex engineered systems have been consistently increasing, with current systems typically experiencing multi-billion dollar development overruns reaching 78% in cost and 63% in schedule. These overruns result, in part, from failures in system functionality or performance that are not discovered until late in the design cycle, necessitating large-scale, costly, and time-consuming rework cycles. These failures are often related to the uncertainty associated with modeling and simulation tools used during the early phases of complex system design. The methods developed in this research are intended to formally track and manage uncertainties and to guide design process decisions to maximize the information obtained during each design task, thereby reducing the potential for undiscovered problems to surface late in a development cycle and reducing the overall budget and schedule required in the design process.
